newsitem.title: SPAIN: Sol Melia aims for 20 pct/yr profit growth.
newsitem.headline: Sol Melia aims for 20 pct/yr profit growth.

text.p: Spanish hotel chain Sol Melia aims to increase its net profits by 20 percent a year on a sustained basis, financial director Oscar Ruiz said.
"The objective consists of raising net profits by 20 percent annually on a sustained basis," Ruiz told financial daily Expansion in an interview published on Monday.
To do so, the company is raising the number of hotels under management and taking advantage of different hotel cycles on the four continents it conducts business, he said.
"We want the market to get used to expecting a dividend of between 25 and 35 percent," Ruiz said.
The financing for growth is drawn solely from company means.
"In our balance sheet we don't have even a peseta of debt and financing is done with equity capital," he said.
Liquid assets that build are put in Treasury bills and in short-term deposits. With these funds, investments are made in hotels the group manages.
"These assets represent some 10 billion pesetas and, if we didn't make any investments, they would grow by five billion pesetas by year end," he said.

When asked how the group managed currency flows, Ruiz said Sol Melia's dollar, dollar-tied, and mark income represents some 30 percent of the total -- 13 billion in 1996 -- and compensates for peseta cycles.
Ruiz said Europe's economic and monetary union would have an essentially positive effect, as it would give stability by eliminating market uncertainties and will ease the hiring of tour operators.
